title: Pouring Water — Pitcher to Glasses
description: The child pours water from one pitcher into two glasses evenly, developing estimation of volume and refined motor control.
instructions:
1. Place a small pitcher filled halfway with water and two empty glasses on a tray.
2. Demonstrate pouring water evenly into both glasses.
3. Compare the water level — are they the same?
4. Pour both glasses back into the pitcher.
5. Let the child practice.
6. Clean up any spills with the sponge.

slides.setup_instructions: Fill the pitcher halfway. Place everything on the tray.

slides.text: Carry the tray to the table. 'Today we'll pour into two glasses and try to make them equal!'
Pour slowly into the first glass — about halfway. Then pour into the second glass.
Look at both glasses side by side. 'Are they the same? Do we need to add a little more to one?'

slides.prompt: Practice pouring evenly into both glasses 3 times. Can you make them match?

slides.text: Pour the water out. Dry everything. Return the tray to the shelf.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child pour approximately equal amounts into two glasses?

parent_notes: This extends the basic pouring exercise by adding the challenge of equal distribution — an early math concept. Don't worry about perfect measurement; the child is developing the eye for estimation. Use real glass when possible — it teaches respect and care for materials.

title: Sandpaper Letter — a (short vowel)
description: Introduction to the first vowel sandpaper letter 'a' (short sound as in 'apple'). The child learns the short vowel sound through tracing and I Spy.
instructions:
1. Present sandpaper letter 'a' (on blue background for vowel).
2. Trace while saying /a/ (short a, as in apple). Repeat 3 times.
3. Child traces and says the sound.
4. Three-period lesson: naming, recognition, recall.
5. I Spy with /a/ objects: apple, ant, ax, alligator.
6. Review: show 's', 'm', and 'a' together.

slides.setup_instructions: Place letter 'a' on the tray. Note the different background color — this is a vowel!

slides.text: 'This letter has a different color background because it's a special kind of letter called a vowel!'
Trace 'a' with two fingers. Say /a/ (short, as in apple). 'aaa — apple!' Repeat 3 times.
Three-period lesson. Then review all three: 'Show me /s/.' 'Where is /a/?' 'What sound is this?'

slides.prompt: I Spy with /a/ objects! Then sort: which objects start with /s/, /m/, or /a/?

slides.text: 'You now know three sounds: /s/, /m/, and /a/! Soon you'll put them together to make words!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the short /a/ sound and distinguish it from /s/ and /m/?

parent_notes: This is the first vowel! In Montessori, vowels are on blue cards and consonants on pink (or vice versa, depending on the set). Always teach the SHORT vowel sound first (/a/ as in apple, not the long sound as in 'ape'). With s, m, and a, the child can soon build their first words: 'am', 'Sam', 'mas'.

title: Number Rods — Full Set 1-10
description: Completing the number rod sequence with rods 8, 9, and 10. The child builds the full stair and practices counting to ten.
instructions:
1. Review rods 1-7 quickly.
2. Introduce rod 8. Count segments together.
3. Introduce rod 9, then rod 10.
4. Build the complete stair 1-10.
5. Count from 1 to 10 touching each rod.
6. Play 'Give me' game: 'Give me the rod that shows 8.'

slides.setup_instructions: You'll need a large workspace — rod 10 is 1 meter long! Lay out the mat.

slides.text: Quick review: build the stair 1-7 together.
Introduce 8, 9, 10 one at a time. Count each rod's segments carefully.
Complete the stair! Stand back and admire. 'Look how it grows from 1 all the way to 10!'

slides.prompt: 'Give me' game: 'Give me eight!' 'Give me the rod that comes after six!' Take turns.

slides.text: Return each rod to the shelf. 'You can count to TEN!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build the full stair and count to 10?

parent_notes: The full number rod stair is impressive — rod 10 is one meter long! This gives the child a truly concrete sense of how 10 is ten times as much as 1. Once the stair is mastered, the child can work with it independently. Extensions include finding combinations that make 10 (1+9, 2+8, etc.).

title: The Globe — Europe, Asia, and Australia
description: Continuing continent exploration with Europe, Asia, and Australia/Oceania on the Montessori globe.
instructions:
1. Review North America, South America, and Africa on the globe.
2. Introduce Europe (red): 'Europe is here — many countries close together.'
3. Introduce Asia (yellow): 'Asia is the biggest continent!'
4. Introduce Australia (brown): 'Australia is the smallest continent — and it's an island!'
5. Play 'Find the continent': name one, child points to it.
6. Count: 'We've learned 6 continents! There's one more — Antarctica!'

slides.setup_instructions: Place the globe at the child's level. Have review cards from last lesson.

slides.text: Review: 'Show me North America. Where is Africa? Find South America!' Praise each correct answer.
Europe (red): 'This is Europe. Lots of countries are packed in here!' Let the child touch it.
Asia (yellow): 'This is Asia — it's the BIGGEST continent!' Australia (brown): 'And here's the smallest!'

slides.prompt: Spin the globe, stop it, and name the continent your finger lands on! Play 5 rounds.

slides.text: 'Six continents learned! Next we'll visit Antarctica — the frozen continent!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate and name at least 4 of 6 continents introduced?

parent_notes: Don't worry about perfection — we'll review continents all year long. The globe-spinning game makes it playful. For older kindergartners, you can start matching continent shapes to the puzzle map. Each continent's color is consistent across all Montessori materials, which helps with recognition.

title: Read-Aloud: The Very Hungry Caterpillar
description: Shared reading of Eric Carle's 'The Very Hungry Caterpillar' with discussion about counting, days of the week, and metamorphosis.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What do you think this story is about?'
2. Read aloud, pausing to count the foods on each page.
3. Point to the holes in the pages — let the child poke fingers through.
4. After reading, review the days of the week.
5. Discuss: 'What happened to the caterpillar at the end?'
6. Sequence: egg → caterpillar → cocoon → butterfly.
materials_needed: The Very Hungry Caterpillar by Eric Carle
Optional: real or plastic butterfly life cycle figures

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Very Hungry Caterpillar by Eric Carle

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together in a cozy reading spot.

slides.text: Cover talk: 'What do you see? What do you think will happen in this story?'
Read aloud. Count the foods together on each page. 'On Monday he ate through ONE apple...'
Let the child interact — poke fingers through the holes, count along with you.

slides.prompt: After reading: 'Can you remember what he ate on Monday? Tuesday? Wednesday?' Review the days.

slides.text: Discuss the life cycle: egg, caterpillar, cocoon, butterfly! 'What a transformation!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the basic sequence of the story?

parent_notes: This beloved book reinforces counting (1 apple, 2 pears, 3 plums...), days of the week, and the life cycle of a butterfly. It connects beautifully to science and math. The repetitive structure supports early literacy. If your child loves it, read it multiple times — familiarity breeds confidence and vocabulary growth.

title: Pink Tower & Brown Stair — Combined Extension
description: Combining the Pink Tower and Brown Stair to explore patterns and creative building. The child discovers new ways to arrange the two materials together.
instructions:
1. Build the Pink Tower and Brown Stair side by side.
2. Show how the smallest cube matches the thinnest prism.
3. Create a combined pattern: alternate tower cubes and stair prisms.
4. Let the child experiment with their own designs.
5. Encourage: 'What else can you build with these?'
6. Photograph any creative constructions.

slides.setup_instructions: Carry all pieces to the mat. Start by building each set correctly.

slides.text: Build the Pink Tower. Build the Brown Stair beside it. 'Look, they match! The biggest cube matches the thickest prism.'
Show: place the smallest cube on the thinnest prism. They're the same width! 'How interesting!'
'Now you can build whatever you like with all 20 pieces! What can you create?'

slides.prompt: Free building! Combine cubes and prisms into new structures. Try a road, a city, a maze!

slides.text: Admire the creation. Take a photo if you like! Then return all pieces to the shelf.
slides.mastery_check: Does the child explore creatively and handle materials with care?

parent_notes: Montessori extensions combine materials in new ways. The child discovers mathematical relationships: the smallest pink cube has the same dimensions as the cross-section of the thinnest brown prism. These 'aha' moments are the magic of Montessori materials. Let the child's creativity guide the construction — there is no wrong answer.

title: Sandpaper Letter — t
description: Introduction to sandpaper letter 't' and its sound /t/. Review of all learned letters: s, m, a, t.
instructions:
1. Present sandpaper letter 't'.
2. Trace while saying /t/ (quick, crisp sound). Repeat 3 times.
3. Child traces and says the sound.
4. Three-period lesson.
5. Review all four letters: s, m, a, t.
6. I Spy with /t/ objects: top, tiger, tape, tree, train.

items: Letters s, m, a for review
slides.setup_instructions: Place 't' on the tray. Keep previously learned letters nearby.

slides.text: Trace 't': straight line down, then cross. Say '/t/' — it's a quick, crisp sound.
Child traces and repeats. Three-period lesson for 't'.
Review all four: lay out s, m, a, t. 'Show me /t/.' 'Where is /a/?' 'What sound is this?'

slides.prompt: I Spy with /t/ objects! Then sort all objects by their beginning sounds: /s/, /m/, /a/, or /t/.

slides.text: 'Four sounds! s, m, a, t. You're building a great collection!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace and identify all four letters?

parent_notes: With s, m, a, and t, the child now knows enough sounds to build their first words with the moveable alphabet! Words like 'mat', 'sat', 'am', 'at', 'Sam', 'Tam'. We'll start word building soon. Keep reviewing — frequent, short practice is better than long, infrequent sessions.

title: Sandpaper Numerals — 6, 7, 8
description: Introduction to sandpaper numerals 6, 7, and 8 with tracing and three-period lessons.
instructions:
1. Review numerals 1-5 quickly.
2. Introduce 6: trace while saying 'six.' Three-period lesson.
3. Introduce 7: trace while saying 'seven.' Three-period lesson.
4. Introduce 8: trace while saying 'eight.' Three-period lesson.
5. Lay out all 8 numerals for random recall.
6. Match numerals 6, 7, 8 to their number rods.

slides.setup_instructions: Review 1-5 first, then present 6, 7, 8.

slides.text: Quick review of 1-5: shuffle and have the child name each.
Introduce 6: trace with two fingers, say 'six.' Curl from the top. Child traces.
Introduce 7, then 8. Three-period lesson for each new numeral.

slides.prompt: Match numerals 6, 7, 8 to their number rods. Then do a full shuffle of all 8 numerals.

slides.text: 'You can recognize eight different numerals now!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify numerals 1-8?

parent_notes: We add 3 numerals at a time now since the child has the pattern down. If your child struggles with 6, 7, and 8 in one lesson, slow down — introduce just one or two. The three-period lesson format (naming → recognition → recall) is always your guide. Watch for reversals of 6 and 9 — this is normal and will resolve with practice.

title: Nature Walk — Collecting and Classifying
description: Second nature walk focused on collecting items and classifying them by attributes: color, texture, size, or type.
instructions:
1. Go on a nature walk with collection basket.
2. Collect 6-8 diverse items.
3. Return to the work area.
4. Classify items by color: 'Put all the green things here, all the brown things here.'
5. Reclassify by texture: rough vs. smooth.
6. Reclassify by type: plant parts vs. mineral/rock.
7. Discuss: 'The same objects can be sorted different ways!'

slides.setup_instructions: Pack the basket. Prepare sorting mats for return.

slides.text: 'Today let's collect items and sort them when we get back! Look for different colors and textures.'
Walk slowly. Collect 6-8 items. Talk about each find.
Back inside, sort by COLOR first. Then re-sort by TEXTURE (rough vs. smooth). Then by TYPE.

slides.prompt: Can you think of your OWN way to sort these items? Big and small? Heavy and light?

slides.text: 'The same objects sorted three different ways! Scientists classify things just like we did.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sort objects by at least 2 different attributes?

parent_notes: Classification is a fundamental science skill. The key insight is that the same set of objects can be sorted multiple ways depending on the attribute you choose. This builds flexible thinking. Keep a nature shelf where collections can be displayed and revisited.

title: Singing — Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes
description: Learning action songs that combine music with body awareness. 'Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes' teaches body parts through movement and rhythm.
instructions:
1. Sing 'Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes' slowly with motions.
2. Touch each body part as you sing.
3. Repeat faster each time.
4. Add a round where you whisper one body part instead of singing.
5. Try 'If You're Happy and You Know It' as a second song.
6. Let the child suggest motions for the second song.
materials_needed: Optional: picture cards of body parts

slides.setup_instructions: Clear some space to stand and move freely.

slides.text: Stand facing the child. 'We're going to sing and move our bodies!'
Sing slowly: 'Head, shoulders, knees and toes, knees and toes!' Touch each part as you sing.
Repeat getting faster each time. Laugh when it gets silly-fast!

slides.prompt: Try whispering 'head' instead of singing it — just touch it silently! Can you remember all the parts?

slides.text: Sing one more time at a comfortable speed. 'Great singing and moving today!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sing along and identify the body parts?

parent_notes: Action songs connect music with kinesthetic learning. The speeding-up challenge builds processing speed and coordination. The 'silent' round (touching but not singing a body part) builds auditory memory. These songs are perfect for transitions and energy breaks throughout the school day.

title: Spooning — Dry Transfer
description: The child uses a spoon to transfer dry beans from one bowl to another, refining fine motor control and concentration.
instructions:
1. Place two bowls on a tray — one with dry beans, one empty.
2. Demonstrate scooping beans with a spoon and transferring to the empty bowl.
3. Show how to hold the spoon steady while carrying it across.
4. Let the child transfer all the beans.
5. Count how many scoops it took.
6. Sweep up any spilled beans.

slides.setup_instructions: Fill one bowl with dry beans. Place both bowls and spoon on the tray.

slides.text: 'Today we're going to move these beans using a spoon — one scoop at a time!'
Demonstrate: scoop a spoonful, hold it level, carry across, pour gently into the empty bowl.
'Your turn! Scoop carefully and carry the spoon straight across. Try not to drop any beans.'

slides.prompt: Transfer all the beans! Count your scoops. Then transfer them back. Did it take the same number?

slides.text: Sweep any spilled beans. Return the tray to the shelf.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child transfer beans with minimal spilling?

parent_notes: Spooning is a key practical life skill that directly prepares the child for self-feeding and cooking. The concentration required to keep the spoon level builds focus. Vary the challenge: start with large beans, progress to smaller lentils or rice. This is a wonderful shelf work for independent practice.

title: I Spy — Review (s, m, a, t) and Oral Language
description: I Spy game reviewing all four learned sounds. Extended oral language practice with descriptive vocabulary.
instructions:
1. Gather objects for all four sounds: s, m, a, t (3 each = 12 objects).
2. Play I Spy, mixing all four sounds.
3. When the child identifies an object, ask them to describe it: 'Tell me about the star. What does it look like?'
4. Practice full sentences: 'The star is yellow and has five points.'
5. Sort objects by beginning sound into four groups.
6. Celebrate the growing sound knowledge!
materials_needed: Objects for sounds s, m, a, t (3 each)
Four sorting mats with letter labels

slides.setup_instructions: Mix all objects together on a large tray.

slides.text: Play I Spy mixing all four sounds: 'I spy something that starts with /t/!'
When found, extend: 'Tell me about this tiger. What color is it? Is it big or small?'
Practice sentences: 'The tiger is orange and has black stripes.' Model rich language.

slides.prompt: Sort all 12 objects into 4 groups by their beginning sound. Put /s/ objects here, /m/ here...

slides.text: Count how many objects in each group. 'You can hear four different sounds now!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sort objects by beginning sound with 80% accuracy?

parent_notes: The oral language extension is crucial. Montessori emphasizes that rich oral language precedes reading and writing. Model descriptive, complete sentences. The sorting activity adds a visual-organizational component. Keep collecting miniature objects — the richer your collection, the more versatile your I Spy games.

title: Sandpaper Numerals — 9 and 10; Full Review
description: Completing the sandpaper numerals with 9 and 10, then a comprehensive review and matching with all number rods.
instructions:
1. Review numerals 1-8.
2. Introduce 9: trace and say 'nine.' Three-period lesson.
3. Introduce 10: trace both digits while saying 'ten.'
4. Full review: shuffle all 10 numerals.
5. Match all numerals to their number rods.
6. 'Now you know ALL the numerals from 1 to 10!'

slides.setup_instructions: You'll need ample space to match all 10 numerals with all 10 rods.

slides.text: Review 1-8 with quick recall. Shuffle and have the child name each.
Introduce 9: 'Almost like 6 but upside down!' Trace and say 'nine.' Three-period lesson.
Introduce 10: 'This needs TWO digits — a 1 and a 0 together make ten!' Trace both.

slides.prompt: Match all 10 numerals to their number rods! Place each numeral at the end of its rod.

slides.text: 'You know every numeral from 1 to 10! That's a huge accomplishment!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify and match all numerals 1-10?

parent_notes: The 10 numeral is significant because it requires TWO symbols. This is a sneak peek at the concept of place value, which will be explored deeply with the golden beads later. Watch for 6/9 confusion — teach the child that 6 has a 'belly' on the bottom and 9 has a 'belly' on the top. Celebrate this milestone!

title: Land and Water Forms — Peninsula and Gulf
description: Second pair of opposite land and water forms: peninsula and gulf. The child explores these through the land/water trays and drawing.
instructions:
1. Review island and lake with the trays.
2. Introduce the peninsula tray: 'A peninsula is land surrounded by water on three sides.'
3. Introduce the gulf tray: 'A gulf is water surrounded by land on three sides.'
4. Pour water into each to demonstrate.
5. 'Peninsula and gulf are opposites — just like island and lake!'
6. Draw and label each form.

items: Island and lake trays for review
slides.setup_instructions: Set up all four trays on towels. Have water and drawing materials ready.

slides.text: Review: 'What is an island?' 'What is a lake?' Let the child explain.
Peninsula: 'Land that sticks out into the water — water on three sides, land on one.' Pour water around it.
Gulf: 'Water that reaches into the land — land on three sides, water opens on one.' Pour water in.

slides.prompt: Draw a peninsula: land sticking out with water around three sides. Then draw a gulf: water going into the land.

slides.text: 'You know four land and water forms now: island, lake, peninsula, and gulf!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define peninsula and gulf and identify them as opposites?

parent_notes: Land and water forms are always presented in pairs of opposites. The opposite relationship helps children understand: where land pushes out (peninsula), water can push in (gulf). Real-world examples make this concrete: Florida is a peninsula; the Gulf of Mexico is a gulf. Point these out on a map or globe!

title: Painting — Exploring Watercolors
description: Introduction to watercolor painting. The child learns how to use a brush, mix colors with water, and paint freely.
instructions:
1. Set up: watercolor tray, water cup, brush, paper, paper towel.
2. Demonstrate: dip brush in water, touch a color, paint a stroke.
3. Show: rinse brush before changing colors.
4. Let the child explore freely.
5. Talk about what happens when colors mix on the paper.
6. Allow the painting to dry. Display.

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the workspace. Put on a smock. Fill the water cup. Lay out materials.

slides.text: 'Today we're going to paint with watercolors!' Show how to put on the smock first.
Demonstrate: 'Dip your brush in water. Touch a color gently. Paint on the paper. See the color flow!'
'When you want a new color: rinse, rinse, rinse in the water. Dab on the paper towel. Then touch the new color.'

slides.prompt: Paint whatever you like! Try different colors. What happens when two colors meet on the paper?

slides.text: Rinse and lay out the brush. Pour out the dirty water. Let the painting dry flat.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child use the brush, rinse between colors, and paint on the paper?

parent_notes: Watercolor is a perfect first painting medium — clean-up is easy and the transparent colors are beautiful. Focus on PROCESS: how to hold the brush, how to rinse, how to control the water amount. The child's painting may look like colored blobs — that's perfect! The goal is exploration, not representation. Display all artwork to show it is valued.

title: Red Rods — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori Red Rods. The child arranges 10 rods from longest to shortest, developing visual discrimination of length.
instructions:
1. Carry each rod to the mat one at a time, starting with the longest.
2. Scatter rods randomly on the mat.
3. Find the longest rod. Place it at the top.
4. Find the next longest. Place below the first, aligned at the left.
5. Continue until all 10 rods form a stair.
6. Run hand along the stair ends to feel the graduation.

slides.setup_instructions: The longest rod is 1 meter! Ensure plenty of space.

slides.text: Carry the longest rod with two hands. 'This is the longest rod!' Place it on the mat.
Bring all rods to the mat. Scatter them. 'Can you find the longest one?'
Build the stair: longest at top, each next rod below, aligned at the left edge.
Run your hand down the right side — feel the staircase shape. 'Each rod is a little shorter!'

slides.prompt: Mix them up and build the stair again by yourself!

slides.text: Return each rod to the shelf. 'You built a perfect staircase!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child arrange all 10 rods from longest to shortest?

parent_notes: The Red Rods isolate LENGTH as the only variable — every rod is the same color and width. This is different from the Brown Stair (width) and Pink Tower (three dimensions). Together, these three materials train the eye to discriminate specific attributes. The Red Rods are the precursor to the Number Rods — same dimensions, but with counting segments added.

title: Metal Insets — Square and Triangle
description: Continued metal inset work with the square and triangle shapes. Building pencil control and shape awareness.
instructions:
1. Select the square metal inset.
2. Trace the frame, then the inset. Fill with parallel lines.
3. Repeat with the triangle metal inset.
4. Encourage the child to choose colors.
5. Compare the two designs: 'The square has straight edges. The triangle has three points.'
6. Display the completed designs.

slides.setup_instructions: Let the child choose their colors today.

slides.text: 'Today you have two shapes to trace! Which do you want to do first?'
Trace the frame with one color. Trace the inset with a second color. Fill with lines in a third color.
Repeat with the second shape. Focus on keeping lines straight and close together.

slides.prompt: Make both designs. Try to fill inside the lines with careful, close-together parallel lines.

slides.text: 'Beautiful designs! Your pencil control is getting stronger.' Display the work.
slides.mastery_check: Are the child's lines becoming more controlled and closer together?

parent_notes: The child may do these quickly or very slowly — both are fine. The goal is the PROCESS of controlled hand movement, not speed. Over weeks, you'll see the filling lines become more parallel, closer together, and more contained within the shape boundaries. This directly translates to handwriting readiness.

title: Number Rods & Numerals — Complete Matching
description: Matching all 10 sandpaper numerals with their corresponding number rods. Connecting abstract symbols to concrete quantities.
instructions:
1. Build the number rod stair 1-10.
2. Shuffle sandpaper numerals 1-10.
3. Pick up a numeral: 'This is 4. Which rod shows four?'
4. Place the numeral at the end of its rod.
5. Let the child match all 10.
6. Count each rod to verify the match is correct.

slides.setup_instructions: Build the rod stair first. Shuffle numerals on the side.

slides.text: Build the stair together. 'Now let's give each rod its number name!'
Demonstrate: pick up numeral 1. 'This says one.' Place it at the right end of rod 1.
'Your turn! Pick a numeral, read it, and find its matching rod.'

slides.prompt: Match all 10! Then play: close your eyes, the parent removes one numeral — which is missing?

slides.text: 'Every rod has its matching numeral! You connected the rods to the numbers!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child match all 10 numerals to rods independently?

parent_notes: This exercise is pivotal: it connects the CONCRETE (rods you can hold and count) with the ABSTRACT (written numerals). This is the heart of Montessori math — always moving from concrete to abstract. The 'missing numeral' game builds memory and attention. Once matched independently, this becomes a shelf work.

title: Antarctica and All Seven Continents
description: Introducing Antarctica and reviewing all seven continents. Singing the continent song and beginning the world puzzle map.
instructions:
1. Review 6 continents on the globe.
2. Show Antarctica (white): 'This is Antarctica — the coldest place on Earth!'
3. 'Now we know all seven: North America, South America, Europe, Africa, Asia, Australia, Antarctica.'
4. Sing a continent song (to the tune of 'Are You Sleeping?' or 'Frère Jacques').
5. Introduce the world puzzle map if available.
6. Identify each continent piece by its Montessori color.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the globe out. If you have a puzzle map, place it nearby.

slides.text: Review: spin the globe slowly. 'Name each continent as my finger touches it!'
Point to the bottom: 'This is Antarctica — covered in ice! Penguins live here, but no one lives here permanently.'
All seven together: name each. Sing the continent song if you know one!

slides.prompt: If using a puzzle map: take out each continent piece and name it. Can you put them all back?

slides.text: 'You know all seven continents! What an explorer you are!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name all 7 continents with visual support (globe)?

parent_notes: A simple continent song (many are on YouTube) makes memorization fun. The puzzle map is a wonderful tactile extension — the child physically holds each continent. Don't expect instant recall of all seven; we'll review throughout the year. Make it fun: 'Which continent is the biggest?' 'Which one is cold?' 'Which one do WE live on?'

title: Read-Aloud: Brown Bear, Brown Bear, What Do You See?
description: Shared reading of Bill Martin Jr.'s patterned text, building prediction skills and color/animal vocabulary.
instructions:
1. Read the title. 'What do you think this book is about?'
2. Read aloud with emphasis on the pattern.
3. After a few pages, pause before the answer: 'Brown bear, brown bear, what do you see? I see a ___' Let the child guess.
4. Discuss the colors and animals.
5. After reading, ask: 'What was your favorite animal?'
6. Invite the child to 'read' the pattern back to you.
materials_needed: Brown Bear, Brown Bear, What Do You See? by Bill Martin Jr.
Optional: toy animals matching the book

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Brown Bear, Brown Bear, What Do You See?

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together comfortably.

slides.text: Show the cover. 'What do you see? What color is this bear?'
Read aloud. Emphasize the repeating pattern. Point to each animal and color.
After 3-4 pages, pause: 'What do you see?' Let the child predict the next animal.

slides.prompt: After reading: 'Now YOU be the reader!' The child 'reads' by remembering the pattern.

slides.text: 'You can almost read this book by yourself! Patterns help us predict.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete the predictive pattern ('I see a ___ looking at me')?

parent_notes: Patterned text is a gateway to reading. The repetitive structure lets the child 'read' before they can actually decode — building confidence and love of books. Color words and animal names expand vocabulary. This book can be read dozens of times; each reading builds fluency and memory. A wonderful book for the child to 'read' to a younger sibling or stuffed animal.

title: Hand Washing — Step by Step
description: Learning the complete hand-washing procedure. A fundamental care-of-self exercise in Montessori practical life.
instructions:
1. Set up the hand washing station: basin, pitcher of water, soap, towel, nail brush.
2. Demonstrate each step slowly and deliberately.
3. Roll up sleeves. Pour water over hands. Apply soap.
4. Rub palms, backs of hands, between fingers, thumbs, nails.
5. Rinse thoroughly. Dry with towel.
6. Clean and reset the station.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up on a low table or stool. Place a towel underneath to catch drips.

slides.text: Roll up sleeves. 'First we prepare ourselves.' Put on an apron if available.
Pour water from the pitcher over your hands into the basin. Take the soap. Rub between palms to lather.
Wash each part: palms together, back of each hand, between each finger, each thumb, under nails.
Rinse by pouring water over hands. Dry with towel — each finger, palms, backs.

slides.prompt: Now you do it! Wash your hands following each step. Take your time.

slides.text: Pour out the basin water. Hang the towel to dry. 'Your hands are clean and you did it all by yourself!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete the hand-washing sequence independently?

parent_notes: In Montessori, hand washing is an art form — each step is deliberate and purposeful. It develops independence, sequence memory, and hygiene habits. The standalone station (rather than a bathroom sink) lets the child control the entire process. Over time, the child will do this completely independently. This exercise has obvious health benefits too!

title: First Word Building — CVC with Moveable Alphabet (sat, mat, am)
description: First experience building words with the moveable alphabet! Using known sounds (s, m, a, t), the child builds their first CVC words.
instructions:
1. Set out the moveable alphabet letters: s, m, a, t (several of each).
2. Say: 'I'm going to say a word slowly. Listen for each sound: sss-aaa-t. sat!'
3. 'What's the first sound? /s/! Find the letter s.' Place it on the mat.
4. 'What's the next sound? /a/! Find a.' Place it next to s.
5. 'Last sound? /t/!' Place it. 'You built SAT!'
6. Build: mat, am, at, Sam. Child builds with guidance.
materials_needed: Moveable alphabet (s, m, a, t letters)

slides.heading: Word Building!
slides.subheading: Your First Words with the Moveable Alphabet

items: Moveable alphabet letters: s, m, a, t
slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the moveable alphabet letters. Place the mat for building.

slides.text: 'Today is a VERY special day. You're going to build your first WORDS!' The child has earned this.
Say 'sat' slowly: /s/ - /a/ - /t/. 'What's the first sound?' Child finds 's'. 'Next sound?' → 'a'. 'Last sound?' → 't'.
Read it together: 's - a - t... sat!' Celebrate! Now build 'mat': /m/ - /a/ - /t/.

slides.prompt: Build these words: am, at, sat, mat, Sam, Tam. Sound out each one as you build it!

slides.text: 'You are a WORD BUILDER! You can make words with letters!' Photograph the words.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build at least 2 CVC words with support?

parent_notes: THIS IS A MILESTONE! The child is encoding — translating sounds to symbols. This is writing before handwriting! In Montessori, children write (build words) before they read. Don't expect the child to READ these words yet — the skill here is BUILDING them from sounds they hear. Celebrate enthusiastically. Some children will be amazed; some will be matter-of-fact. Both responses are fine.

title: Number Rod & Numeral Matching — Independence
description: Independent practice with number rod and numeral matching. The child works through the full matching exercise on their own.
instructions:
1. Invite the child to take out the number rods and numerals.
2. 'Today, I'd like YOU to do the whole matching by yourself.'
3. Observe without intervening.
4. Only assist if the child asks or becomes frustrated.
5. When complete, verify together by counting each rod.
6. 'You did the whole thing independently!'

slides.setup_instructions: The child carries everything to the mat independently.

slides.text: 'Today you get to do this all by yourself! Build the stair and match the numerals.'
Observe quietly. Resist the urge to correct. Note any rods or numerals placed incorrectly.
If the child makes an error and doesn't notice: after completion, count together to verify.

slides.prompt: Do the complete exercise independently: build the stair, match all numerals, then verify by counting.

slides.text: 'Wonderful independent work! You did that all on your own.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete the exercise independently with no more than 1 error?

parent_notes: This is a test of independence — a core Montessori value. Sit nearby but don't intervene. Mistakes are learning opportunities; the child may self-correct when counting to verify. If they don't, gently count together: 'Let's check — this rod has... one, two, three, four, five, six. And this numeral says... seven. Hmm, do those match?' Let the child discover and fix the error.

title: Sink or Float — Simple Experiment
description: A hands-on science experiment exploring which objects sink and which float. The child makes predictions and tests them.
instructions:
1. Fill a basin with water.
2. Gather 8-10 objects: rock, leaf, cork, coin, plastic toy, apple, key, sponge, wooden block, paper clip.
3. For each object: 'Do you think this will sink or float?' Record the prediction.
4. Test it! Drop the object in the water.
5. Was the prediction correct?
6. Sort tested objects into 'sink' and 'float' groups.
7. Discuss: 'What do the floating things have in common?'

items: Assorted objects: rock, leaf, cork, coin, toy, apple, key, sponge, block, paper clip
slides.setup_instructions: Fill the basin. Lay out objects and a towel. Prepare a simple chart: two columns labeled 'sink' and 'float.'

slides.text: 'Scientists make predictions — guesses about what will happen — and then test them!'
Hold up the first object (rock). 'Will this sink or float? What do you think?' Record the guess.
'Let's find out!' Drop it in the water. 'It sank! Were you right?' Continue with each object.

slides.prompt: Test all the objects! Make your prediction first, then test. How many did you get right?

slides.text: Dry objects off. 'What did you notice about the things that floated? They were mostly light or had air in them!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child make predictions and describe why some objects float?

parent_notes: This is the scientific method in its simplest form: hypothesize (predict), test (experiment), and analyze (discuss results). Don't worry about teaching 'density' at this age — the intuitive experience of seeing heavy things sink and light things float builds the foundation. Some results will surprise the child (an apple floats!) — these surprises are the best learning moments.

title: Music Appreciation — Listening to Classical Music
description: Guided listening experience with a piece of classical music. The child learns to listen actively and express what the music makes them feel.
instructions:
1. Choose a short classical piece (suggested: Vivaldi's 'Spring' from The Four Seasons, 3-4 minutes).
2. 'We're going to listen to music and see what we notice.'
3. Play the piece once — just listen.
4. 'How did that make you feel? Was it fast or slow? Loud or soft?'
5. Play again — this time, draw while listening.
6. 'What did you draw? How does it connect to the music?'

slides.setup_instructions: Set up in a quiet space. Have drawing materials ready but set aside for first listen.

slides.text: 'Today we're going to LISTEN to a beautiful piece of music. Close your eyes and listen.'
Play the piece (3-4 minutes). Sit quietly together. Model attentive listening.
'What did you hear? Was it fast or slow? Loud or quiet? How did it make you feel?'

slides.prompt: Listen again — this time, draw what the music makes you see or feel. Let your crayon dance to the music!

slides.text: 'Your drawing is music you can see! Different music makes us feel different things.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe at least one quality of the music (fast/slow, loud/soft)?

parent_notes: Music appreciation is a lifelong gift. Start with short, expressive pieces. Vivaldi's Four Seasons, Saint-Saens' Carnival of the Animals, and Prokofiev's Peter and the Wolf are all wonderful for young children. There's no wrong response — if the music makes them want to dance, let them dance! The goal is engaged, active listening rather than passive background music.
